passage:
(1) Dreams have fascinated humans for thousands of years, yet scientists are still working to fully understand why we dream. When we sleep, our brains cycle through different stages, with dreams primarily occurring during Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep. During this phase, our brain activity increases significantly, resembling patterns seen while we're awake, despite our bodies being temporarily paralyzed to prevent us from acting out our dreams.

(2) One prominent theory suggests that dreams help process emotions and memories. During sleep, our brains sort through the day's experiences, strengthening important memories and discarding less significant ones. This may explain why we sometimes dream about events or concerns from our waking lives. Some researchers believe that dreams serve as a form of emotional regulation, helping us work through difficult feelings in a safe environment.

(3) Another theory proposes that dreams function as a kind of mental rehearsal. By simulating threatening or challenging scenarios, dreams might prepare us to face similar situations in real life. This could explain why many dreams contain elements of danger or conflict. From an evolutionary perspective, individuals who rehearsed potential threats in their dreams might have gained a survival advantage.

(4) The content of dreams varies widely between individuals and cultures. While some people report vivid, colorful dreams with complex narratives, others experience simpler or more abstract dream states. Factors such as age, medication, stress levels, and sleep quality can all influence dream content and recall. Interestingly, studies show that most people forget approximately 95% of their dreams shortly after waking.

(5) Modern research uses advanced technology like MRI scanners to observe brain activity during sleep, providing new insights into the dreaming process. Some scientists are even developing methods to record and visualize dream content, though this technology remains in its early stages. As we continue to study dreams, we may gain deeper understanding not just of why we dream, but of consciousness itself, potentially revealing new information about how our minds work both during sleep and when we're awake.

questions.question: Which form is grammatically correct?

options.A: She don't like coffee.
options.B: She doesn't likes coffee.
options.C: She doesn't like coffee.
options.D: She not like coffee.

questions.question: Choose the correct past tense form.

options.A: I goed to the store yesterday.
options.B: I gone to the store yesterday.
options.C: I went to the store yesterday.
options.D: I going to the store yesterday.

questions.question: Select the correct preposition.

options.A: We arrived to the airport early.
options.B: We arrived at the airport early.
options.C: We arrived on the airport early.
options.D: We arrived in the airport early.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the present perfect correctly?

options.A: I have saw that movie last week.
options.B: I have seen that movie last week.
options.C: I have seen that movie three times.
options.D: I have see that movie yesterday.

questions.question: Choose the correct modal verb.

options.A: You must to go now.
options.B: You should going now.
options.C: You must go now.
options.D: You should to go now.

questions.question: Which is the correct comparative form?

options.A: This exercise is more easy than the last one.
options.B: This exercise is easyer than the last one.
options.C: This exercise is easier than the last one.
options.D: This exercise is the easier than the last one.

questions.question: Select the correct future tense form.

options.A: I will meeting my friend tomorrow.
options.B: I am going to meet my friend tomorrow.
options.C: I meet my friend tomorrow.
options.D: I will meets my friend tomorrow.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a grammatical error?

options.A: She has been working here for two years.
options.B: They have lived in this town since 2010.
options.C: He has gone to Paris last month.
options.D: We have known each other for a long time.

options.A: The book was wrote by a famous author.
options.B: The book was written by a famous author.
options.C: The book was writed by a famous author.
options.D: The book is written by a famous author yesterday.

options.A: She is the best student in an class.
options.B: I bought a umbrella because it was raining.
options.C: He plays the guitar in a band.
options.D: We saw an unicorn in the forest.

questions.question: Select the correct conditional form.

options.A: If it rains tomorrow, we stay at home.
options.B: If it rains tomorrow, we will staying at home.
options.C: If it will rain tomorrow, we will stay at home.
options.D: If it rains tomorrow, we will stay at home.

questions.question: Which is the correct question form?

options.A: Where you are going?
options.B: Where are you going?
options.C: Where going you are?
options.D: Where you going are?

questions.question: Choose the correct relative pronoun.

options.A: The woman who car I borrowed is my neighbor.
options.B: The woman which car I borrowed is my neighbor.
options.C: The woman whose car I borrowed is my neighbor.
options.D: The woman whom car I borrowed is my neighbor.

questions.question: Which sentence uses adverbs correctly?

options.A: He drives careful on busy roads.
options.B: She sings beautiful in the choir.
options.C: They work hardly on their projects.
options.D: We finished the test quickly.

questions.question: Select the correct reported speech form.

options.A: She said that she is coming tomorrow.
options.B: She said that she was coming the next day.
options.C: She said that she will come tomorrow.
options.D: She said that she comes the next day.

questions.question: Choose the correct expression to complete the sentence: 'I'm not sure if I'll pass the exam. I haven't studied _____.'

options.A: good enough
options.B: well enough
options.C: enough good
options.D: enough well

options.B: look for

options.C: making
options.D: taking

options.A: do

options.D: have

options.A: so

options.D: I saw by her at the supermarket yesterday.

options.D: I couldn't hear where she was saying because of the noise.

options.A: I'm feeling badly today. I think I might be sick.
options.B: I'm feeling bad today. I think I might be sick.
options.C: I'm feeling worst today. I think I might be sick.
options.D: I'm feeling more bad today. I think I might be sick.

options.B: Don't touch on the paintings in the museum.
options.C: Don't touch the paintings in the museum.
options.D: Don't touch for the paintings in the museum.

options.A: The dinner smells well.

options.C: The dinner smells nicely.
options.D: The dinner smells good smelling.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence with 'taste':

options.A: This soup tastes too salt.
options.B: This soup tastes too saltly.
options.C: This soup tastes too salty.
options.D: This soup tastes too salting.

questions.question: Which sentence uses 'need' correctly?

options.A: She needs studying more for her exam.
options.B: She needs to studying more for her exam.
options.C: She needs study more for her exam.
options.D: She needs to study more for her exam.

questions.question: According to paragraph 1, when do dreams primarily occur?

options.A: During deep sleep
options.B: During Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep
options.C: When we are about to wake up
options.D: During the first hour of sleep

questions.question: What does paragraph 2 suggest is one function of dreams?

options.A: To prevent memory formation
options.B: To generate new ideas
options.C: To process emotions and memories
options.D: To rest the conscious mind

questions.question: According to paragraph 3, why might dreams contain elements of danger?

options.A: To cause insomnia
options.B: To create entertaining narratives
options.C: To prepare us for threatening situations
options.D: To reflect our daily fears

questions.question: Based on paragraph 4, what percentage of dreams do most people remember?

options.A: About 50%
options.B: About 5%
options.C: About 95%
options.D: Less than 1%

questions.question: What technology is mentioned in paragraph 5 as being used to study dreams?

options.A: EEG machines
options.B: CT scanners
options.C: MRI scanners
options.D: Sleep monitors

questions.question: The word 'prominent' in paragraph 2 is closest in meaning to:

options.A: new
options.B: well-known
options.C: complicated
options.D: interesting

questions.question: What does the passage state about brain activity during REM sleep?

options.A: It decreases significantly
options.B: It resembles patterns seen while awake
options.C: It stops completely
options.D: It becomes more regular

questions.question: According to the passage, which of the following can influence dream content?

options.A: Genetic factors only
options.B: Diet and exercise
options.C: Weather conditions
options.D: Stress levels and medications

questions.question: What is the main purpose of paragraph 3?

options.A: To explain why dreams are frightening
options.B: To present a theory about dreams as mental rehearsal
options.C: To argue that dreams have no purpose
options.D: To describe common dream narratives

questions.question: What does the passage suggest might be a broader implication of dream research?

options.A: Better medication for sleep disorders
options.B: More effective memory improvement techniques
options.C: Understanding consciousness and how minds work
options.D: The ability to control dreams completely
